{Migraine with aura: Migraines can cause headaches as well as sensory disturbances such as parasthesia. Weakness can occur during or after a migraine attack.}, {Tension headache: While typically not associated with weakness or parasthesia, tension headaches are very common and could be present alongside another condition causing these symptoms.}, {Multiple sclerosis (MS): This autoimmune disease affects the central nervous system and can cause a wide range of symptoms, including weakness, parasthesia, and headaches.}, {Stroke: Although less common for all three symptoms to appear together, a stroke should be ruled out immediately as its a medical emergency. Weakness and parasthesia are typical, while headaches can occur.}, {Brain tumor: Headaches are a common symptom of brain tumors, and depending on the location, weakness and parasthesia can also occur.}, {Vitamin B12 deficiency: This deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms such as weakness, parasthesia, and headaches.}, {Diabetes: High blood sugar levels over prolonged periods can cause nerve damage (diabetic neuropathy) leading to weakness, parasthesia, and headaches.}, {Lyme disease: This tick-borne illness can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms, including weakness, parasthesia, and headaches.}, {Fibromyalgia: This condition causes widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and often neurological symptoms like parasthesia and headaches. Weakness can be present due to pain and fatigue.}, {Anxiety or panic disorder: Severe anxiety and panic attacks can sometimes cause physical symptoms like headaches, weakness, and parasthesia, although this is less likely as the primary cause.}
